Row.Text: Gold generated from trade routes passing through your empire based on city connections.
Roads on or adjacent to Holy Sites providing +1 Gold, +1 Production, and +1 Faith.
City is converting Gold and Production into Faith through the Tithe process.
Faith generated from converting 30% of Gold and Production through Tithe.
Marker for Corvée unit spawning during Tithe.
Faith bonus from Chölön missions based on City-State connections.
Zimchongpa is garrisoned in this city, providing connection to capital.
City is connected to capital via Zimchongpa garrison and provides Tithe benefits.

Convert 30% of this city's[ICON_GOLD]Gold and[ICON_PRODUCTION]Production into[ICON_PEACE]Faith. When purchasing units with Faith during Tithe, spawn a Corvée copy in your Capital (lasts 20 turns with -25%[ICON_STRENGTH]CS, cannot earn XP).

The Tithe process is unique to Tibet under Ralpachen. It converts a portion of your city's Gold and Production into Faith, allowing you to focus on religious development. More importantly, any combat unit purchased while a city is running Tithe will spawn a weaker Corvée copy in your capital, effectively doubling your military production at the cost of unit quality. Use this to quickly build defensive armies or prepare for rapid expansion.

Ralpachen, also known as Tritsuk Détsen, was the third Dharma King of Tibet, whose reign marked both the apex of Buddhist patronage and the beginning of the empire's decline. Known for his extraordinary devotion to Buddhism and generous support of the monastic community, he transformed Tibet into a theocratic state where spiritual and temporal power became inseparable. His name, meaning "Long Hair," refers to his practice of allowing monks to sit upon his braided hair during religious ceremonies.

Under Ralpachen's rule, Tibet controlled crucial sections of the Silk Road, extracting immense wealth from trade caravans passing between China, India, and Central Asia. He established a sophisticated system of tolls and taxes, while ensuring the safety of merchants through military garrisons stationed at strategic mountain passes. This control of trade routes filled the imperial treasury, funding his extensive religious projects and military campaigns.

Ralpachen's devotion to Buddhism was unprecedented among Tibetan rulers. He decreed that seven households should support each monk, effectively creating a vast religious welfare system. Thousands of new temples were constructed, while existing monasteries received generous endowments. He invited Indian scholars to continue the translation of Buddhist texts, completing the monumental task begun by his predecessors. His reign saw the creation of standardized Buddhist terminology that remains in use today.

In 821 CE, Ralpachen negotiated the historic Sino-Tibetan Peace Treaty with Tang China, establishing borders and ensuring peace between the two empires. The treaty, inscribed on stone pillars in both Lhasa and Chang'an, recognized Tibet and China as equals, referring to them as "uncle and nephew." This diplomatic achievement secured Tibet's eastern borders and allowed Ralpachen to focus on internal development and religious activities.

Ralpachen introduced revolutionary economic policies, including the Tithe system where a portion of all production was dedicated to religious purposes. He established a corvée labor system for public works, building roads that connected holy sites and facilitated both pilgrimage and trade. His reign saw the introduction of standardized weights and measures, as well as a sophisticated taxation system that balanced religious obligations with economic needs.

Ralpachen's excessive religious spending and favoritism toward the Buddhist clergy eventually provoked a backlash from the aristocracy. In 841 CE, he was assassinated by supporters of his brother Langdarma, who would reverse his Buddhist policies and persecute the monastic community. Despite his violent end, Ralpachen is remembered as the most devout of Tibetan emperors, whose reign represented the culmination of the Tibetand Empire's Buddhist golden age. His economic and religious innovations influenced Tibetan governance for centuries to come.

Honor to you, Ralpachen, Third Dharma King of Tibet and devout patron of Buddhism, whose piety and wisdom brought unprecedented prosperity to the Land of Snows! You controlled the great Silk Road caravan routes of Asia, extracting wealth from every merchant train while ensuring their safe passage through your formidable mountain realm. Under your reign, the Tibetan Empire stretched from the scorching oases of the Tarim Basin to the emerald plains of Bengal, and from the lofty Pamir mountains to the distant provinces of Gansu and Yunnan in China. Even the mighty Tang Empire was compelled to treat with you as an equal: you forged a lasting peace and inscribed its terms on stone pillars in Lhasa and Chang'an, a testament to your diplomacy and sagacity.
In your zeal for the Dharma, you raised temples across the high plateau—legend holds you built one thousand shrines to glorify the Buddha. Among these was a magnificent nine-tiered temple crowned with a golden roof, built to house sacred scriptures and learned sages Your innovative Tithe system transformed temporal wealth into spiritual merit by assigning the revenue of seven households to sustain each monk under your protection, ensuring the monastic order flourished throughout your domain. Meanwhile, armies built roads over rugged passes, binding holy monasteries with bustling market towns in every corner of your realm. Under your enlightened rule, merchants doubled as missionaries, carrying the Dharma to foreign lands along with their wares, while soldiers stood as guardians of the faith, protecting the realm and its sacred sites from all threats. Your intrepid Chölön spread the dharma, while your formidable warriors ensure that even the most remote mountain citadel remains connected to the beating heart of your empire.
Now, pious sovereign, Tibet calls upon your wisdom once more. Will you master the Silk Road and make trade routes generate untold wealth from your vast network of city connections? Can you bring harmony to the six realms? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time?
It is regrettable that a friend would act with such duplicity. The Dharma teaches us to see through illusion, and I see your true intentions now.
You have chosen the path of violence. Know that the empire will not falter before your aggression.
Though my empire falls, the teachings of the Buddha endure. May you find wisdom in victory.
So, you declare war. The wheel of fate turns, and your actions will be judged.
Your expansion encroaches upon lands sacred to my people. Restraint is a virtue you would do well to learn.
I am Ralpachen, King of Dharma. May our meeting be auspicious.
Our relations are strained, yet I remain steadfast. The empire will not be cowed by hostility.
We meet as equals, neither friend nor foe. Let us see what the future holds.
Welcome. May our dealings be marked by wisdom and respect.
Your armies gather at my borders. Do not mistake patience for weakness.
Let us trade in the spirit of prosperity. May both our peoples benefit.
Open borders may foster trust, but I will not allow my empire to be exploited.
Do not covet the lands of Tibet. Such actions will not be tolerated.
Your request will be considered. The Dharma guides my generosity.
Denounce me if you must, but truth is not found in slander.
Friendship is earned, not given lightly. Let us build trust before formal bonds.
Peace cannot be rushed. Let wounds heal before we speak of reconciliation.
Your actions trouble me. I must speak out for the sake of all beings.
Let us walk the path of friendship, guided by wisdom and mutual respect.

Trade Routes passing through your land grant Gold per City Connection. Roads on or next to Holy Sites yield +1[ICON_GOLD]Gold,[ICON_PRODUCTION]Production, and[ICON_PEACE]Faith. Cities may Tithe to convert Gold / Production to[ICON_PEACE]Faith and spawn extra purchased units.

Unique Great Merchant replacement. Conducting a mission on a City-State grants[ICON_PEACE]Faith instead of[ICON_GOLD]Gold and +10%[ICON_PEACE]Faith from the mission per distinct City-State you have a City Connection with. Can be expended to construct a Holy Site instead of a Customs House.

The Chölön is a unique Great Merchant replacement for the Tibetan Empire. Unlike regular Great Merchants, Chölön generate Faith instead of Gold when conducting trade missions with City-States, with bonuses based on your trade network. They can also construct Holy Sites instead of Customs Houses, providing both defensive benefits and yields. Use Chölön to spread your faith through commerce while building a network of fortified holy places.

The Chölön were monk ministers of the Tibetan Empire, wielding immense influence in state affairs. They oversaw taxation and managed business operations for the great monasteries, which became the economic engines of the empire. Through their guidance, monasteries grew into powerful centers of commerce and administration, driving both spiritual and material prosperity across Tibet.

Unique Longswordsman replacement. Faster and stronger when starting turn on a Hill or adjacent to a Mountain. When garrisoned in a City, the City is connected to the Capital and provides the bonuses of Tithe regardless of what the City is producing.

The Zimchongpa is a unique Longswordsman replacement for the Tibetan Empire. It excels in mountainous terrain with combat and movement bonuses. More importantly, when garrisoned in a city, it creates a connection to your capital and automatically provides Tithe benefits without requiring the city to run the Tithe process. Use Zimchongpa to defend frontier cities while maintaining your economic and religious network.

The Zimchongpa were the heavy infantry of the Tibetan Empire, renowned for their formidable defense and terrifying presence on the battlefield. Outfitted in advanced Tibetan armor crafted with superior metallurgy, these warriors gained an edge over their opponents and were feared for their resilience. The sight of the red-checked Tibetan ranks, bristling with heavy shields and weapons, struck fear into enemy armies and became a symbol of Tibetan military might.
+15%[ICON_STRENGTH]Combat Strength on Hills and when adjacent to Mountains
+15%[ICON_STRENGTH]Combat Strength on Hills and when adjacent to Mountains
-20%[ICON_STRENGTH]Combat Strength, cannot earn XP. Unit expires after 20 turns.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Corvée unit spawned![ENDCOLOR] Will expire in {1_Turns} turns.
A Corvée unit has expired and been disbanded.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Chölön mission complete![ENDCOLOR] +{1_Faith}[ICON_PEACE]Faith ({2_Bonus}% bonus from {3_Connections} CS connections)
Zimchongpa garrison: {1_CityName} is now connected to capital and has Tithe benefits!
Tithe active: Converting Gold and Production to Faith

Replace.Text: If the unit is inside a City State's territory that you're not at war with, this order will have the unit conduct a trade mission, giving you a large amount of [ICON_GOLD] Gold and improving relations with the City State. It consumes the Great Person.
